review_title: Management Killed My Trust in the Company
pros: - Decent work life balance if your boss is good - Exciting opportunity to work in tech growth businesses - Working level people tend to have great camaraderie - Benefits includes staff rates for broadband and mobile plans
cons: - Ridiculous KPIs, usually top-down. - Management is not transparent with working level & usually don't address working level concerns until desperate. - Insincere promotion and retention offers, company HR policies don't help either. - Sometimes, even good bosses cannot do anything to help you if their bosses don't help them. - many departments work in silos

review_title: There are subcultures having different values from its "True" culture
pros: Purpose driven - Singtel inculcates a strong purpose into its people which is a good thing because it gives them direction and motivation to soldier on during tough times.
cons: Lack of autonomy - seems to me that the higher management doesnt really have the full trust of its people. Although Singtel prides itself of having a good, strong and ethical culture, its processes, systems and abilities lack depth to inculcate them into the lower levels i.e., ground people. Example, it prides itself as a culture of being open and gives room for its people to make small incremental mistakes in a low-risk environment, but if the leader of that team doesn't practice that, well.. that team is well out of luck. AND, the deadliest mistake of all - working in silos. Having worked with various internal stakeholders from different BUs, most, but not all, are obtuse to processes outside of their BU's scope. Without realising how it would impact their own BU's processes. That's ignorance at its best. And, that's dangerous.

review_title: Old style management with no opportunity for young talents
job_title: Senior Customer Care Officer in Singapore
pros: Colleagues and teammates are jovial and great to work with. Some colleagues will become like family. Once you are a permanent staff, you are almost guaranteed your job till retirement. Group insurance provided by the company and you may join union if you like. Good for those whose education Qualifications is up to O levels.
cons: There are several long time staffs who are supervisors for over 20 to 30 years. Some have joined the company when they were 17 year old and now pushing 65 years. Although retirement is 62, they are offered reemployment on a yearly basic until 68. The main issue with this is that these staffs are supervisors for decades amd still in management role after retirement. They don't accept new ideas and their education qualifications are stagnant since 1970s. Because of these fresh polytechnic graduates are unable to assume their roles and there is little room for fresh blood to climb the ladder. Many young and potential staffs resign and jump to another company instead. Salary is low if you compare to industry standards. They pay increment is only 2 digits on a yearly basis or on an average 1 to 3% of the base pay. Even if you get promoted, it is 3 to 4% of the base pay and not attractive enough. There is practically no WFH or Flexible work routine in Customer Operations or customer service. The company shows in LinkedIn and in the press that they practice hybrid work routine but for majority of Customer care in consumer operation, this is non existent. Even during Covid, there is no WFH. For a company that boost that they are industrial leader for innovation and technology, this is rather backwards. When questioned why there is WFH, they will give excuses such as PDPA and unable to bring Customer details home. In current times, even banks and government employees who are handling sensitive information are allowed to work from home. There is no half day or time off before major public holidays. They follow a clean desk policy where no handphone, paper, pen or bag allowed in the office. You will have to place them in the locker. Breaks and lunch are monitored.

review_title: Singtel is a place to learn and grow - If you have Entreprenurial mindset.
pros: If you can understand Singtel's end to end IT infrastructure, you can work anywhere in the world. Wonderful exposure to all the vendor ecosystems. you get to learn what's happening in the market. Supportive management and shorter hierarchy. Lesser approvals to get things done. Continuous Technology Adoption
cons: Working here is like an unorganized crime sometimes - No documentation. challenging for new joiners to adapt quickly. Takes time and need patience. All projects delivery is super slow. Need skills to overcome. Salary Bench mark is slightly lower. Median is at ~70%. Not so bad too. Some departments have legacy infra - cleanup in progress.

pros:
- Huge group, so alot of opportunities to rotate around (esp for highly sought after skillsets)

- some teams are quite committed to working hard for the customers, even if it means longer hours
cons:
- regular reorg (so alot of time spent worrying about their job and who's their boss and how things will change)
- culture wise is quite fragmented across Groups and different teams within each Group
- lack of commitment from upper management to adequately resource and commit money to grow revenue (ie have a headcount freeze and no backfill when people leave, leading to an overworked existing team and expecting them to deliver the same or higher targets)
- OR commit money but expect ROI within the year (for non-core or new businesses, where it may not be reasonable)
- in some areas, too top down style or middle managers do not push against top down directives cause its too difficult, easier to just follow, scared of blowback etc.
- heavy push for automation and streamlining work but processes and systems does not support or create circumstances to enable that

pros:
Job security 
Learning opportunities in handling different customers.
Understand telecom structure, how they work.
cons:
They will use you absence as a reason to undermine your work. Especially during year end reviews. Promotions will be denied. It will definitely affect your “performance” as they deemed this portion under “adherence”. So if you are on approved urgent leave (reported within 3 days) or if you are on medical leave, these affect your adherence. And this in turn affect your KPI even if you were on time for work.
Fast paced environment with changes happening frequently - product information can change on a weekly basis. At times the same information can be changed over and over and at times could be conflicting. For clarity, customer allowed to recontract without fee upon completion of certain mths of contract, later they can remove this and thus increasing their own group of unhappy consumers.

The pay is really bare minimum.
They will pressure you to do OT due to operational needs. They will plot the OT for you and if you don’t turn up, this affect your adherence and in turn KPI. when you request to remove OT, they will ask you for valid reasons.

review_title: Overwork employees instead of trying to understand and improve the process
job_title: Corporate Operation & Customer Service in Singapore
pros:
The peers, the colleagues
The location
Flexibility (in terms of time off and work arrangement especially for staffs who need to take care of their family and kids)
cons:
- High workload
- High staff turnover rate
- Only "try" to retain experienced staffs after they tender resignation
- Red tapes everywhere
- Autocratic management
- Delusional director, setting high impossible target. 
- Director do not back his own staffs against Sales or Product team 
- Too much product customization from Sales and Product, but staffs have to remember everything 
- Have to provide valid reason and preventive measure when the mistake is clearly due to overlook. Overlook/forget is not acceptable
- Overloaded staffs who seek help from management are advised to work overtime to clear backlog. 
- no work life balance
- Existing staffs are forced to help team that are under crisis, on top of their own work
- Training are done by operation staffs on top of their own duties
- Uses inhouse system which is slow and often having issue that result in provisioning error. Yet encourage customer to self help via the system to save headcount. 
- Forced to work overtime on certain weekend during crisis
- Not able to WFH during covid due to access to certain system 
- No point feedback to Managers or HR about the grievance because it will be ignored or entertained with excuses during townhall or skipped level meetings.

review_title: Great Place to Kick Start Career
pros:
- High level of autonomy
You get to be part of decision making process and make a real change to the company. This is largely so as when MAs enter Singtel, they are given a higher job grade than normal fresh grad, and hence the higher responsibility. That is the level of confidence and challenge that fresh grads should crave for if you are looking for an exciting but yet challenging career for start. 
- Nurturing Leaders
High Challenge, High Support. The MAP has been ongoing for many years and many Middle Management to Senior Leaders are onboard this journey altogether to provide MAs a chance to learn. 
- Structured Programme 
2 years, 2 rotations. You get to have an in-depth understanding of the role you are doing by staying 1 year / rotation. There are about 100+ roles for an MA to choose from, as Singtel has many business units (Consumer, Enterprise etc).
- Above avg pay compared to other MAP
cons:
- Many legacy systems (as per many MNCs) 
- Decision making process at times can be long (as per many MNCs), but new GCEO is appointed, new tagline of "empowering every generation", looking forward to a culture change

review_title: Decent employers particularly for early careers
pros:
- Potentially have the opportunity to move around other roles and teams, provided you have a good relationship with the direct manager (they are primary gatekeepers)
- At par health benefits, decent pay (could be better)
- Good brand, comes with resources
- Great for early-career - you get the opportunity to do A LOT hence can gain more experience.
- Research the team you are joining and the culture within the team as it will be your key to either success or failure
cons:
- Highly hierarchical, political, and red tape (company-wide)
- Personal experience with bullying, passive-aggressive behavior from direct managers, very toxic, anxiety-inducing environment (particularly in my team)
- No work, life balance, all support is lip service, good on the paper type of initiative
- 360 evaluation doesn't exist. 
- The employee survey is not exactly confidential. We were sat down as a team to explain why we marked it low and asked to find the solution (yeah, ridiculous, this happens widely)
- Only 2 kinds of people: overworked and underworked. If you are underworked and coasting, your boss likes you, and he is influential enough to cover you.

review_title: A job Not For the Weak.
pros:
Below are my only opinion.

Pay- Thumbs up
Medical - Thumbs up - need to co-pay5 buck but sometime free. I still cant figure this one out.
Recreations - Dude! Free zoo, science centre and etc passes! My kids love them
Discounts - got so many discounts coming to inbox. I just delete them. Don't want to spent.

The Job:

To succeed, you need to learn to be independent! yes there are support but you don't wait for them to come! You need to chase them. You need to learn on your own, pickup new technology, be an initiator! 
I don't know is not an answer, if that is, seek it before it is being ask. Learn beyond your scope, understand the culture and seek to improve!

In no time, months will go by, years will pass, and who you are right now is very much different from you were 10 years ago when you entered.
cons:
If you are not an achiever, a visionary, a performer. You will feel gloom and doom. Not because of lack of resources, Not because lack of help, not because lack of time. 

It because you don't fit in. You will feel demoralize because you are not able to perform. Don't get me wrong here. The job is of your character. Support provided are great! Resources are superb! 

If you goes your day as a salaryman, nope. This don't fit you. Too many people with goals, determination and achievers. You'll be haunted with too much tasks because of lack of efficiency. 

My advise do something you like. When you're done move to the next. Explore life.

review_title: I can see Singtel is changing from the inside, in a much better way to embrace challenges
pros:
Working on real, big projects. Anyone here has been selected for a reason, they have some abilities and skills which are better than another, we can learn from everyone. 
People are humble, especially mid, hight level executive and managers. I know they are very experienced but very humble.
Tons of courses are free to learn, update your skills quickly.
Gym, Club, Discount Code, etc
Office located next to one of the most beautiful place in Singapore, very professional, and believe me, the smell of the office is so nice, like a 5 stars hotel.
cons:
There are legacies and outdated technologies, like any big corporation, the transformation is slower than a startup, but it is happening.
People (tech and non-tech) with a traditional mindset(fixed mindset), sometimes it causes conflict with the people with an agile mindset.

pros: Family friendly, work life quite balance with understanding bosses.
cons: The recent resignation rates across the organisation is alarming. People are burnt out as there’s no replacement of those who have left. Headcount freeze is always the reason. Those left behind are to carry the burdens and responsibilities (managers are expected to work like directors) and execs are expected to work like managers and added scopes. Understand the need to cut costs and be prudent but pls think for the ones left behind if it’s fair for one employee to be hard carrying 2 persons job whilst doing their own. Promotion is not given or recognised. There seems to be streamlining measures across the board but also more initiatives to roll out. The burn out is real, while words of encouragement is appreciated, we need REAL hands onboard.

review_title: Good company if you are lazy or good at politics and blame game.
pros:
Telecommunication is expensive in Singapore, the only good reason to join Singtel is the staff discount.
Work life balance - Apply for an access and you can take a vacation.
cons:
1. Growth - it will take you forever to learn something new if you are experience.
2. Processes - You will be stuck in process forever
3. Onboarding time - Takes you 2-3 months to get onboard (laptop setup, software installation etc). you need to get permission to install chrome.
4. Feedback - Whenever you try to raise concern/feedback for the team, people start giving you advices like chill before the storm comes etc etc. Nobody wants to improve. Nobody cares if you are happy or not everybody is just doing their job by the books. If you have joined the company by mistake please i beg you never be candid about your opinions people will start hating you, stop talking to you. Also never correct any person who is superior to you, you will be dropped out of the future meetings.
5. IT support - Try not to visit them, you will end by wasting your life there.
6. Approvals - Apply for an access and go have a bag packing trip in Europe for 20 days. 
7. Mails - Please take a crash course for email writing before joining. You will end up writing mails the whole day. 
8. HR - I seriously do not have words to describe the HR. I was new, got an injury, kept pinging the HR about the medical policy and all, he did not care to respond back. End up paying from my pocket.
9. My manager was changed without any prior notice.
10. Below market standard pay.
11. No transparency.

review_title: It all depends on the specific team you are in, and how "smart" you are. Not how hard you can work!
pros:
First things first and this place is probably one of the few local firms who can offer international exposure. Salaries are not bad and total take home in an year is around the median pay of the industry. Solid brand name and typically people are good and helpful. Plenty of 'me too' policies for visibility and plenty of work-life balance noise. 
Holidays/Annual leave is better than local small firms, or some international firms too.
cons: Biggest issue is HR. Almost useless people are filled this department. "me too" stuff and not real policies from heart. Be it work-from-home or any other. There is a plenty of cynicism around, and people love to use "last time when we're working at your position,...." stories. Growth is slow and if you are working hard, people may not appreciate it and you need to maintain the 'relation' with a sr.leader to grow. Steoreotyping is common and for some people it can be a shocking experience to hear such comments from such a big company.

review_title: It has the intent to change and innovate but too many baggages
pros: Above the average benefits. It is relatively more pro-family and it will respond to national initiatives which is one good way to make employees feel important. Middle-management is generally good in terms of running telco business.
cons:
Many tried to voice concerns or ideas through organization wide initiatives such as Be Heard, Heads-up Tuesday, open forum in comms session with TMs etc but it is always challenging to cut loose (useless) baggage that is already irrelevant to consumers even with management support. Most of the times, you will have to face greater challenge from others, deal with more objections.

This is a place where you really need unusually high challenger spirit and energy to "push" things through. You definitely feel satisfying once you made it but few years later, you feel tired.

Sometimes it can be very scary when you are expecting to see a group of people in a meeting and out of sudden you feel like losing the courage to deal with them, to try convince them no matter how much preparation you have done and how strong your case is.

So if you are expecting collaborative environment and a place where people and ideas are treated seriously and with respect, you should try checking out the environment and the team that you are going to work with first.
